alt_statements.statement: I think we have to protect the environment because our kids are the ones who will live with what we leave behind, but we can’t just shut down jobs that families depend on overnight. The government should push companies to be cleaner—like using greener energy and cutting pollution—while also making sure workers get training and support so they don’t lose their income. For me, real growth means people have good jobs, clean air, and safe neighborhoods at the same time, not one instead of the other.

I think we should protect nature first, because God made the earth and we’re supposed to take care of it, but adults should still find smart ways for people to have jobs and make money without hurting the planet so much. Grown-ups should invent cleaner machines and energy so businesses can keep going, but they should have rules so they don’t pollute the air and make the weather worse for kids like me when we grow up.

As someone who worked in healthcare and now lives simply on almost nothing, I’ve seen how environmental damage and extreme weather hit everyday people first, especially those without a safety net. We shouldn’t pretend it’s a choice between jobs and the planet—good climate policy should create new, decent-paying work in clean energy and infrastructure while phasing out the worst polluters. I’d rather see us invest in protecting our air, water, and climate now than pay the price later in medical bills, disasters, and lost communities. Economic growth that destroys our environment isn’t real progress; it needs to be measured by how well it protects people and the places we call home.

As a mom and a student thinking about my kids’ future, I believe we need to protect the environment, but we can’t do it in a way that destroys jobs or makes life unaffordable for working families. Climate policy should focus on practical, market-based solutions and new technology that reduce emissions while still allowing businesses to grow and communities to thrive.

Environmental protection is important, but we can’t ignore the livelihoods of working families and the stability of our economy in the process. I believe climate policy should focus on gradual, practical measures—like encouraging cleaner technology and rewarding responsible businesses—rather than heavy-handed regulations that kill jobs and drive up costs for ordinary people. We should be good stewards of God’s creation, but in a way that respects personal responsibility, energy independence, and economic freedom.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because my generation is the one that’s going to live with the long‑term damage if we don’t act now. But I also get that people need jobs and communities depend on certain industries, so climate policies should help create new, cleaner kinds of work instead of just shutting things down. If we invest in green technology and better infrastructure, we can grow the economy in ways that don’t destroy the planet.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short-term profits ahead of the world we leave our children, and it isn’t pretty. Climate policy should put environmental protection first, with economic growth reshaped around clean energy, conservation, and green jobs rather than fossil fuels and waste. We’re creative enough as a society to build an economy that thrives without destroying creation, and government has a moral responsibility—one I see as deeply Catholic—to protect the most vulnerable people and ecosystems from climate harm.

As someone who works in a state-run food service and cares deeply about my community, I believe climate policy has to put environmental protection first while still respecting the need for stable jobs and economic security. We can’t keep chasing short-term growth if it destroys the air, water, and climate our neighborhoods depend on, but we also have to invest in a just transition—training workers, especially in working-class and immigrant communities, for cleaner, better-paying jobs. For me, real economic growth means healthier communities, more resilient local food systems, and policies that hold big polluters accountable instead of leaving ordinary people to pay the price.

I supervise a cleaning crew for a living, and I see every day how regulations and costs hit small, service-based businesses first. I still think we need strong climate policy, because protecting our environment is non-negotiable, but it has to come with real support for workers and small employers—grants, tax credits, and clear, practical rules instead of vague mandates. If we do it right, investing in clean energy and efficiency can create better, more stable jobs for people like my crew while cutting pollution, instead of forcing us to choose between our paychecks and the planet.

As someone who’s spent a career in healthcare research and sees firsthand how environmental conditions affect people’s health, I believe climate policy must put environmental protection first, but in a way that doesn’t leave working people behind. We can and should invest in clean energy, public transit, and green jobs that create real economic opportunity, especially in vulnerable communities, rather than propping up industries that harm both the planet and public health.

I believe we have a responsibility from God to be good stewards of the earth, but we also need to protect jobs, family incomes, and the stability of our communities. Climate policies should encourage practical, gradual changes—like promoting cleaner energy and conservation—without crippling small businesses, farmers, or people on fixed incomes. We should focus on realistic, cost-effective solutions that use American innovation instead of sweeping mandates that hurt the economy.

As someone who worked for years making sure a small, community-focused financial institution stayed healthy, I believe we need climate policies that protect God’s creation without strangling the jobs and savings that families depend on. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions and new technologies that reduce emissions over time, rather than heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and rural communities. A strong economy gives us the resources to invest in cleaner energy and better stewardship, so the two goals ought to work together instead of being set against each other.

Look, at my age I’ve seen what happens when companies are allowed to pollute first and apologize later, and it’s always working people and poor communities who pay the price. We don’t have to choose between clean air and good jobs—especially in a country as rich and innovative as ours—but we do have to stop pretending that short‑term profits are more important than a livable planet. Climate policy should put strong environmental protections first while investing heavily in clean industries, retraining workers like me, and making sure no community gets left behind in the transition.

I believe we have a responsibility before God and to our grandchildren to be good stewards of the earth, but we also have to use common sense so we don’t destroy people’s livelihoods in the process. Climate policies should encourage practical steps like cleaner technology, conservation, and American energy independence, without piling on regulations and costs that hurt small businesses and working families.

As a working mom and the main breadwinner for my family, I believe climate policy has to protect both the environment and people’s livelihoods, not sacrifice one for the other. We should encourage innovation and practical solutions—like cleaner trucks, better fuel standards, and incentives for businesses to cut emissions—rather than heavy-handed regulations that could kill jobs or raise costs for families. I want cleaner air and a healthy planet for my kids, but I also want them to grow up in a strong economy where hard work is rewarded.

As someone who makes a modest living as a working musician, I understand how fragile people’s livelihoods can be, but I also see climate change as an even bigger threat to our long-term economic and personal well-being. I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, with strong investments in clean energy and green jobs so workers and small businesses aren’t left behind. We shouldn’t accept the false choice between the planet and paychecks—smart regulation, innovation, and fair transition support can grow the economy while honoring our moral responsibility, as a Catholic and a citizen, to care for creation and for each other.

I believe we need a climate policy that protects our land, air, and water without strangling the jobs and industries that keep families like mine afloat. We should invest in cleaner, more efficient technologies and common‑sense regulations that cut waste and pollution, but changes need to be gradual and practical so energy costs don’t skyrocket and working folks aren’t left behind. Environmental protection matters, but it has to go hand in hand with strong economic growth, not be pitted against it.

My mamá and papá tell me that we have to take care of “la tierrita” God gave us, so I think protecting the environment should come first, especially for kids like me who will live here a long time. But I also know my family works hard and money can be tight, so climate policies should help people get good jobs in clean energy and not make it harder for families to afford what they need. If we’re careful and smart, we can have both clean air and water and a strong, fair economy for everyone.

I think we should take care of the Earth first, because it’s like our home and we need it to stay clean and safe for when I grow up. Grown‑ups can still make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt the air, trees, and animals so much.

As someone who cares a lot about the environment and still sees how important money and jobs are for families like mine, I think climate policy should push hard for clean energy and green jobs instead of pretending we have to choose between the planet and the economy. We should invest in things like public transit, energy‑efficient housing, and green small businesses so working people can afford a good life while we cut emissions. Honestly, if we trash the environment now, there won’t be a stable economy later anyway, so long‑term growth has to be based on protecting the climate first.

I think we should take care of the earth first, because it’s like our home that God gave us, and we have to keep it clean and safe for animals and kids like me. Grown‑ups can still make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t make the air dirty or hurt the trees and oceans. If we protect nature now, then when I’m a grown‑up there will still be a nice world where people can work and live happily.

As someone who values both stewardship of God’s creation and the stability of our local economy, I believe climate policy should aim for a practical middle ground. We should invest in cleaner technologies and energy efficiency where it makes sense, but we must avoid regulations that would cripple small businesses, raise costs too quickly for working families, or threaten jobs in our community. Thoughtful, gradual changes that encourage innovation and personal responsibility—rather than sweeping mandates—are the best way to protect the environment while keeping our economy strong.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because my generation is the one that’s going to live with the worst consequences if we don’t. But I also know a lot of families, especially in Latino communities, depend on jobs that could be affected by climate rules, so climate policy should invest in clean energy, job training, and support for workers. To me, real economic growth means creating sustainable jobs that don’t poison our air and water, not just chasing profits right now.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put short‑term profits ahead of the air we breathe and the water we drink, and it’s never worth the cost. We need strong climate policies that treat environmental protection as non‑negotiable, while investing in clean energy and green jobs so the economy grows in a healthier direction. Economic growth that destroys the planet my grandchildren will inherit isn’t real progress.

At this stage of my life, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals so much as badly managed priorities. Climate policy should put strong, enforceable environmental standards first and then spur innovation and good jobs—especially in clean energy and resilient infrastructure—within those guardrails. We’ve let short‑term profits drive decisions for too long, and it’s time to accept that a stable climate and healthy communities are the foundation of any durable, fair economy.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we wreck the planet, there won’t be any economy left to grow. But that doesn’t mean no jobs or no progress—we should invest in clean energy, green tech, and better public transit so people can still work and make money without trashing the air and water. Big companies that pollute a lot should pay more and be pushed to change faster, instead of regular people always taking the hit.

As a management consultant and an immigrant from Chile who has seen both economic struggle and environmental fragility, I don’t see climate policy as a choice between protection and growth, but as a mandate to redesign growth itself. We should set firm, science-based environmental limits and then drive innovation, investment, and job creation within those boundaries—using tools like carbon pricing, clean energy incentives, and strong regulations. In the long run, a stable climate is a precondition for a healthy economy, and responsible businesses will adapt and thrive under clear, consistent rules.

As someone who runs a small skincare business and cares deeply about natural ingredients and a healthy environment, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and must do both. Climate policy should prioritize strict environmental standards and rapid decarbonization, while also investing in green jobs, small businesses, and sustainable industries so that workers and communities aren’t left behind. If we build our economy around renewable energy, regenerative agriculture, and eco-friendly products, we’ll protect the planet and create more stable, long-term prosperity.

Working in community outreach in the film industry, I see firsthand how powerful stories can shift public attitudes, and I think climate policy needs to clearly prioritize environmental protection while supporting workers and local communities through the transition. Economic growth that destroys ecosystems or worsens climate change isn’t real prosperity—it just pushes costs onto vulnerable people and future generations. We should invest heavily in clean energy, green jobs, and sustainable infrastructure so that economic opportunity and environmental responsibility reinforce each other instead of being treated as opposites.

As a young dad working in a pretty physical job, I want my kids to grow up in a world with clean air and a stable climate, but I also need policies that don’t wipe out working-class jobs or jack up our basic costs overnight. I think we should push hard on clean energy and efficiency, with strong environmental standards, but pair that with serious investment in retraining, good union jobs, and support for communities that depend on old industries. Environmental protection should set the direction, and economic growth should come from building the new green economy in a way that doesn’t leave regular families behind.

As someone who works in education and thinks a lot about the world my students and my own kids will inherit, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing forces so much as priorities that have to be intelligently aligned. We should pursue economic growth that is tied to sustainable practices—investing in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs—so that we’re not borrowing against our children’s future for short-term gains. Sound climate policy should be grounded in evidence, protect vulnerable communities, and give schools and local communities the resources they need to adapt and innovate.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we prioritize short-term profit over the air we breathe and the water we drink, and it’s always the most vulnerable who pay the highest price. I believe environmental protection has to come first, and our economic growth should be measured by how well we care for people and the planet—through good green jobs, cleaner communities, and policies that look beyond the next quarterly report.

I believe we need a sensible middle ground where we protect the environment without crippling the economy that working folks and retirees like me depend on. Climate policies should focus on practical innovations—like cleaner manufacturing technologies and energy efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that drive up costs or send jobs overseas. We should move toward cleaner energy, but do it gradually and realistically so we don’t sacrifice American competitiveness or put too much burden on families.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because without a healthy planet there won’t even be an economy for my generation to grow up into. That doesn’t mean we ignore jobs and businesses, but climate policy should push companies and governments to create green jobs, cleaner energy, and sustainable tech instead of just letting them pollute for short‑term profit. If we invest in things like renewable energy and public transit now, it can help the economy grow in a way that’s actually fair to people and to nature.

As a physician, I see every day how health is inseparable from the environment we live in—air quality, heat, and pollution all show up in my patients’ charts—so I can’t accept the idea that economic growth should come at the cost of a livable planet. My faith and humanitarian values push me toward policies that aggressively reduce emissions and protect vulnerable communities, while still supporting innovation, green jobs, and just transitions for workers. We should treat environmental protection as a non‑negotiable foundation and design our economy around it, not the other way around.

Working in entertainment and community art, I see how creative economies and environmental health actually reinforce each other, not compete. Climate policy should prioritize strong environmental protection—especially cutting emissions and preserving ecosystems—while investing in green jobs, sustainable infrastructure, and support for industries (including the arts) to transition. Economic growth that destroys the planet isn’t real progress; we should be aiming for growth that’s cleaner, more resilient, and opens up new opportunities rather than clinging to polluting models of the past.

As someone who’s spent his career in computer systems, I see climate policy as an optimization problem, not a binary choice between the environment and economic growth. We should set firm, science-based environmental constraints (like emissions caps) and then use market mechanisms, innovation incentives, and clear regulations to let businesses compete on efficiency and clean technology. In the long run, a stable climate is basic economic infrastructure, and smart climate policy can create high-skill jobs and new industries instead of just adding costs.

At my age, having watched rivers I knew as a girl run lower and summers grow harsher, it’s clear to me that economic growth built on a ruined climate is a false prosperity. We should treat environmental protection as the frame within which all responsible economic activity must fit, not an optional constraint to be bargained away. That means investing aggressively in clean energy, conservation, and green jobs, even if it slows or reshapes traditional growth, because the true economy we bequeath is the stability of air, water, and land our grandchildren will depend on.

As someone who works in restaurants and cares a lot about food, I see how climate change can threaten everything from ingredients to jobs, so I think protecting the environment has to come first, but in a way that doesn’t crush small businesses and workers. We should push hard for clean energy, efficiency, and less waste, while investing in training and support so regular workers and local businesses can adapt and actually benefit from greener policies.

I believe climate policy has to protect the environment without crippling the industries and transportation systems that keep this country running. We should invest in practical, proven technologies that reduce emissions over time, while preserving jobs, keeping energy affordable, and maintaining strong infrastructure. Heavy-handed regulations that hurt workers and drive businesses overseas do more harm than good, both economically and environmentally. A realistic, gradual approach that encourages innovation and efficiency—not mandates and shutdowns—is the right balance.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when we put economic growth ahead of clean air and water, and it’s our kids and grandkids who pay the price. I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, with strong investments in green jobs and support for workers and small businesses so no one is left behind. We’re creative enough as a country to grow an economy that respects the planet instead of exhausting it, and we owe that to the next generation living under our roofs.

I think we need to protect the environment, but we also can’t ignore that people like me depend on steady work to support our kids. Climate policy should push companies to cut pollution and invest in cleaner technology, but it has to come with job training, affordable energy, and support for workers so we’re not the ones paying the price. If we do it smart, we can create new, better-paying jobs in clean industries instead of just shutting things down.

As a dad and someone who works in a business that depends on people driving, I think we’ve got to be smart about climate policy so it protects the environment without crushing working families’ budgets. We should push cleaner technologies and energy efficiency in ways that create good jobs and keep gas and utility prices manageable, instead of sudden rules that make it hard for regular folks to get to work or support their kids. I believe we can balance both by phasing in realistic standards, supporting innovation, and helping workers and small businesses adapt, rather than treating the economy and the environment like they’re enemies.

As someone who works in healthcare and is raising young kids, I think we can’t afford to treat environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need both, and smart policy can encourage cleaner industries and good jobs at the same time. I support climate policies that set clear, science-based standards and timelines, but also give businesses incentives and flexibility to innovate rather than just punishing them. For me, the priority is protecting our children’s long-term health and future, while making sure working families like mine aren’t crushed by sudden costs or job losses during the transition.

Mira, from where I stand, we don’t have a real economy if we don’t have a livable planet—so climate policy has to put environmental protection first, then design growth around that reality. We should invest heavily in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and green jobs, especially in communities like mine that have seen both military service and neglect, so people aren’t forced to choose between a paycheck and their children’s future. Economic growth that trashes the air, water, and coasts—like we’ve seen in Puerto Rico after storms—isn’t growth, it’s a debt we’re dumping on the next generation.

As someone who works in manufacturing and cares deeply about my kids’ future, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposing goals—we should be using smart regulation and innovation to drive both. Climate policy ought to push industry toward cleaner technologies through clear standards and incentives, so companies like mine can plan ahead, stay competitive, and create good jobs while sharply reducing emissions.

We need a sensible balance where we protect our land and resources without strangling the economy that families depend on. I want policies that encourage practical, cost‑effective solutions—like cleaner technology and better energy efficiency—without punishing businesses, raising utility bills, or killing jobs. Climate policy should be gradual, rooted in sound science rather than political fashion, and respectful of the freedoms and livelihoods of ordinary Americans.

I think we need a climate policy that protects the environment without killing the very jobs and businesses that keep our communities alive. I work in building materials, and I see firsthand how higher costs and regulations hit working folks and small contractors, not just big corporations. We should invest in cleaner technologies, energy efficiency, and responsible resource use, but do it in a way that encourages innovation and growth instead of top‑down mandates that punish the economy. God gave us this earth to steward wisely, and that includes both caring for nature and making sure people can work, build, and provide for themselves.

As a working mom and nurse, I want my kids to grow up with clean air and water, but I also know how much our family and community depend on good jobs and a strong economy. Climate policy should encourage innovation, responsible energy development, and conservation without crushing small businesses or driving up costs for ordinary families. We should focus on practical steps—like supporting cleaner technologies, improving energy efficiency, and using our natural resources wisely—rather than sweeping mandates that hurt workers. Protecting God’s creation and protecting people’s ability to provide for their families have to go hand in hand.

As someone who spends most of his free time outdoors watching birds, I see every day how fragile our ecosystems are—and how quickly we could lose them if we treat climate policy as optional or secondary to short-term profits. Economic growth matters, especially for working families and the health care sector I work in, but it has to be built on a foundation of aggressive emissions cuts, clean energy investment, and protections for biodiversity. We should set strong environmental standards and then let innovation and markets work within those guardrails, rather than weakening the rules to chase quick growth. In the long run, a stable climate and healthy environment are prerequisites for any sustainable economy.

As someone who manages people and processes for a living, I see climate policy the same way I see a well-run office: cutting corners might boost short-term numbers, but it creates bigger, costlier problems down the line. We don’t have to choose between environmental protection and economic growth; with smart standards, investment in clean energy, and support for workers during transitions, we can build a more stable, innovative economy that doesn’t wreck the planet.

Para mí, el cuidado del medio ambiente es importante, pero también sé que muchas familias, como la mía, dependen de trabajos en fábricas y en la industria. Creo que el gobierno y las empresas deben buscar formas de producir con menos contaminación sin cerrar fuentes de empleo, ayudando a las compañías a modernizar sus máquinas y capacitar a los trabajadores. No podemos elegir solo entre el planeta o el trabajo; necesitamos un plan que proteja ambos poco a poco, para que la gente trabajadora no sea la que pague todo el costo.

As a business manager, a dad, and an immigrant who chose this country, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need climate policy that aggressively cuts emissions while driving innovation, better jobs, and long‑term competitiveness. I’d rather see us invest in clean energy, resilient infrastructure, and science‑driven standards now than saddle my kids with the costs of climate disasters later, both moral and financial.

I think protecting the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a good future for anyone’s jobs or money anyway. But I don’t think we should just shut everything down; we should use science and new technology to make cleaner energy so people can still work and support their families. Governments and businesses should invest more in things like solar and wind power, even if it costs more now, because it will pay off later for both the Earth and the economy.

As someone who spends weekends outside with my kids and sees firsthand how much they thrive in clean air and open spaces, I think environmental protection has to set the boundaries within which economic growth happens, not the other way around. We can absolutely grow our economy, but it needs to be through green jobs, clean energy, and smarter infrastructure that don’t mortgage our kids’ futures. As a teacher, I want to be honest with my students: kicking the can down the road on climate might look like growth on paper, but it’s a bad deal for their generation.

As someone who’s built a good career and a stable life here, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we need smart climate policies that drive innovation, create green jobs, and protect the communities that are usually hit first and worst by pollution and extreme weather. My values as a liberal, a Jewish woman, and an immigrant from Trinidad and Tobago push me to support aggressive climate action with strong safeguards for workers and small businesses, so the transition is fair and doesn’t leave anyone behind.

I think we need a realistic balance where we protect the environment without putting too heavy a burden on working families and small businesses. I’m all for cleaner air and water for my grandkids, but climate policies should focus on innovation, practical technology, and American energy independence instead of harsh regulations that kill jobs and raise prices.

My mommy and daddy tell me we have to take care of the world God made, like not making the air and water dirty, so all the kids can grow up healthy and play outside. I think the people who make the rules should pick choices that don’t hurt the trees and animals, even if it means changing how some jobs work, because we can always find new ways to make money, but we can’t get a new Earth.

I think we should take really good care of the trees, animals, and air first, because if the Earth gets too sick, people and jobs will get hurt anyway. Grown‑ups should use their money and inventions to make cleaner ways to work and build things, so we don’t have to pick between having jobs and having a safe planet.

I think we need to protect the land and water God gave us, but we’ve also got to be realistic about keeping good jobs and affordable energy, especially for working folks and retirees on fixed incomes. Climate rules shouldn’t cripple manufacturing or drive everything overseas where they pollute even more; instead, we should encourage cleaner technology, American-made energy, and practical steps that don’t wreck the economy.

As someone who works in manufacturing and spends a lot of time outdoors hiking and watching birds, I believe we need a climate policy that protects the environment without strangling American industry. We should invest in practical, market-driven innovations—like cleaner production methods and better efficiency—rather than heavy-handed regulations that cost jobs and raise prices. Strong businesses and a strong economy give us the resources to be good stewards of God’s creation, so the goal should be smart, balanced policies that keep our air and water clean while allowing companies and workers to thrive.

As a mom raising kids in a busy city and working in a public school, I see every day how bad air and extreme heat hit regular working families first, especially in Black communities like mine. I don’t think we should pick between the environment and the economy—good climate policy should clean up our neighborhoods, create stable, well-paying green jobs, and protect workers who might lose old jobs in the process. We can invest in cleaner schools, better public transit, and affordable energy while making sure people like me aren’t left behind in the transition.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because it’s our only home and my generation will be the ones living with the consequences. But I also get that people need jobs and money, so I’d like to see more investment in things like clean energy and green tech that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting stuff down. If we’re smart and plan ahead, we don’t have to choose between a healthy planet and a strong economy—we can build both at the same time.

I think taking care of the environment should come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be a good place for anyone to live or work in the future. Grown-ups should still try to make money and have jobs, but they should do it in ways that don’t hurt animals, trees, and the air we breathe. If we’re fair and smart about it, we can have new kinds of jobs that protect nature instead of destroying it.

As an engineer in manufacturing and someone who spends a lot of time outdoors, I think we need climate policies that push industry to innovate rather than just punish it. Strong environmental protections are non‑negotiable, but they should be paired with incentives and support to help companies retool, protect jobs, and develop cleaner technologies. For me, real economic growth in the long run means cleaner air and water in communities like mine, not short‑term profits that leave us with long‑term damage.

As someone who works in home health care and sees how vulnerable people are to heat waves, air pollution, and disasters, I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, but in a way that creates new, decent jobs and doesn’t leave working families behind. We should aggressively invest in clean energy, public transit, and resilient infrastructure, while supporting workers and small businesses through the transition so economic growth comes from protecting people’s health and communities, not from sacrificing them.

As someone who makes a living as an independent musician, I see firsthand how fragile both our environment and our economic stability can be, especially for people who aren’t protected by big institutions. I think climate policy has to put environmental protection first, because a damaged planet ultimately destroys any possibility of sustainable growth—but it should do so by actively investing in green industries, cultural work, and local communities so that people can thrive while we transition. We shouldn’t accept the old narrative that jobs and the planet are in conflict; instead, we should be funding innovation, clean energy, and the arts as part of a more humane, low-carbon economy.

I worked hard my whole life, and I know people need jobs and affordable energy to survive, so we can’t just shut things down overnight in the name of the environment. At the same time, as a Buddhist I believe we should respect the earth and avoid waste, so I support practical steps that don’t crush small businesses or raise costs too much—like improving efficiency, cleaning up local air and water, and encouraging new technology when it proves itself. Government should move slowly and carefully, focusing on common‑sense rules instead of heavy-handed regulations that hurt working families.

I think we need to protect the environment first, because if the planet gets messed up, there won’t be a good future for jobs or the economy anyway. At the same time, climate policies should help create new kinds of work and technology so families and businesses don’t get crushed by sudden changes. It seems fair to make big companies that pollute the most take more responsibility, while regular people get support to switch to cleaner options. In the long run, clean energy and protecting nature should be seen as part of economic growth, not something that competes with it.

As someone working in manufacturing and seeing how jobs depend on steady business, I don’t think we can ignore the economy when we talk about climate policy—but we also can’t keep treating the planet like it’s disposable. We need strong environmental regulations that push companies to clean up and innovate, paired with support and retraining so workers don’t get left behind. To me, real growth is when we create good-paying, green jobs that protect our communities’ health and future. As a liberal and a Christian, I see caring for creation and for working people as the same responsibility, not competing priorities.

At my age, I’ve watched our economy grow and change many times, but I’ve also seen how careless growth can damage the land and climate we all depend on. I believe we should treat environmental protection as the foundation of economic policy, not an afterthought—investing in clean energy, conservation, and green jobs that create opportunity without sacrificing our grandchildren’s future. As a retired teacher, I think of it like a long-term lesson plan: short-term profits should never outweigh the long-term well-being of people and the planet.

As someone who spent a lifetime in finance, I believe we need a climate policy that protects the environment in a way that is fiscally responsible and supportive of long-term economic growth. We should prioritize market-based solutions, technological innovation, and incentives for private investment in cleaner energy rather than heavy-handed regulation that could strangle jobs and industry. Environmental stewardship is important — as a Catholic, I see caring for creation as a duty — but it must be balanced with policies that keep America competitive, safeguard retirees’ savings, and avoid burdening working families with excessive costs.

As someone who works in restaurants and cares a lot about the environment, I don’t think we have to choose between protecting the planet and having a strong economy—especially in food and energy. Climate policy should push businesses, including restaurants, to cut waste, use cleaner energy, and source sustainably, while offering support and incentives so workers and small places can adapt without losing their livelihoods. If we invest smartly in green tech and sustainable practices now, we’ll get more stable jobs, lower long-term costs, and a healthier environment down the line.

At my age, I worry about the kind of world we’re leaving for the young people I volunteer with, so I think protecting the environment has to come first, but it doesn’t mean we ignore people’s economic needs. We should invest in clean energy, public transit, and climate-resilient infrastructure in ways that create good jobs, especially for working-class and immigrant communities like the one I came from. Economic growth that destroys our air, water, and coasts isn’t real progress; growth should be measured by how well people and the planet are doing together.

Where I’m from, we know you can’t poison your own well and expect the town to thrive, and that’s how I feel about the planet and the economy. We absolutely need strong environmental protections, but they should be paired with policies that help small businesses like mine adapt—lower energy costs, green incentives, and job training for new industries—so we’re not left behind. Climate policy ought to put working people first, especially in communities of color that already bear the brunt of pollution. If we’re smart and fair about it, we can grow good jobs while keeping the air, water, and land healthy for the long haul.

As someone working in manufacturing and trying to raise my kids on a decent but hard-earned income, I don’t think we can treat environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies. We need strong climate policies that push companies—mine included—toward cleaner technologies and less waste, but they should also protect good-paying jobs and make the transition affordable for working families. If we invest in green tech, retraining, and smarter regulations, we can create new kinds of manufacturing jobs instead of just shutting plants down. I want my kids to have both a stable future on this planet and the chance at solid middle-class work.

I think we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to protect people’s livelihoods and keep the cost of living reasonable, especially for folks on fixed incomes like mine. Climate policies should encourage practical, affordable steps—like cleaner energy and better efficiency—without shutting down businesses, raising energy prices too fast, or putting American workers at a disadvantage.

Having spent my career as an engineer, I tend to see this as a problem of smart design rather than choosing one side over the other: we need climate policies that push cleaner technologies and efficiency without pulling the rug out from under working people and small businesses. Environmental protection has to be non-negotiable in the long term—this is the only planet we’ve got—but the transition should be gradual, practical, and supported with real investments in jobs, training, and infrastructure.

As a young mom trying to stretch every dollar on a modest income, I really feel that climate policy has to protect both the planet my child will grow up in and the jobs families depend on right now. We shouldn’t treat environmental protection and economic growth as enemies; smart policies can create new green jobs, improve public transit, and cut pollution that harms our health, especially in working-class and immigrant communities. I want the government to invest heavily in clean energy and efficiency, but also provide strong support and retraining for workers and small businesses so no one is left behind. As Catholics say, we’re called to care for creation and for the poor at the same time, not choose between them.

At my age, I’ve seen how hardworking people, especially in healthcare and other modest jobs, depend on a strong economy to keep food on the table and medicine paid for. I believe we should protect God’s creation and be good stewards of the earth, but climate policies must be practical, gradual, and not crush small businesses or drive up costs for ordinary folks on fixed incomes. I’d support cleaner technology and reasonable regulations that encourage innovation and American energy independence, rather than heavy-handed rules that hurt jobs and raise utility bills.

At my age, I’ve seen what happens when companies cut corners on the environment, and it’s always regular people and their communities who pay the price in the long run. I think we need climate policies that protect our air, water, and weather first, but that also help ordinary workers and small businesses adapt—things like support for retraining, incentives for cleaner technology, and help for communities that rely on older industries. Economic growth that destroys the environment isn’t real progress; real growth should mean good jobs, healthy neighborhoods, and a livable planet for the next generation.

As someone who makes a living as an artist and cares deeply about the natural world, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we just need to redefine growth so it doesn’t depend on destroying our only home. Climate policy should prioritize strict environmental safeguards and rapid decarbonization, and then channel investment into green jobs, renewable energy, public transit, and conservation that create long‑term, sustainable prosperity. I’d rather accept slower, more carefully regulated growth now than saddle future generations with irreversible damage and massive costs from climate disasters.

I believe we’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to protect families’ livelihoods and our community’s economic stability. Climate policies should encourage innovation, responsible energy use, and conservation without crushing small businesses or driving up costs so much that working parents can’t make ends meet. We should focus on practical, market-based solutions, not sweeping regulations that hurt American workers while other countries ignore the rules.

I think climate policy should lean toward protecting the environment, because my generation is the one that’s going to live with the long-term damage if we don’t. At the same time, I get that people need jobs and businesses need to function, so we should push for cleaner technologies and renewable energy that create new kinds of work instead of just shutting things down. As Catholics, we’re taught to take care of God’s creation and look out for others, so I feel like it’s our responsibility to find solutions that protect the planet while still letting families make a living.

I believe we have a responsibility from God to be good stewards of the earth, but we also have to be practical and protect people’s livelihoods. Climate policies should encourage cleaner technologies and sensible conservation, without punishing manufacturers and small businesses with heavy regulations and costs they can’t afford. We should move toward cleaner energy gradually, in ways that keep electricity and gas affordable for seniors like me who live on a fixed income.

As someone who has lived long enough to see the climate change around me, I believe protecting the environment has to come first, even if it means slowing certain kinds of economic growth. Any “growth” that destroys the planet we’re leaving to future generations isn’t real progress; it’s just borrowing against their well‑being. That said, I think we can and should create jobs and new industries through clean energy and conservation, so that working people aren’t left behind as we transition to a more sustainable economy.

At my age, having seen both the boom years of unrestrained industrial growth and the mounting evidence of climate change, I’m convinced that environmental protection must set the boundaries within which economic growth is allowed to occur. A healthy economy ultimately depends on a stable climate and intact ecosystems, so serious investment in clean energy, efficiency, and sustainable infrastructure is not a drag on prosperity but its precondition. We should use the best science and technology available, coupled with smart regulation and market incentives, to steer industry and finance toward low-carbon solutions rather than pretend we face a choice between jobs and the planet.

I spent my life making a living off the land, so I know you can’t just strip it bare and expect to keep farming, but you also can’t cripple folks’ livelihoods in the name of climate policy. We ought to focus on practical, gradual steps that protect our soil, water, and air—like encouraging better farming practices and sensible conservation—without hammering small businesses and rural communities with expensive regulations. Let innovation and market incentives do more of the work, instead of top‑down mandates that don’t understand how things actually run on the ground.

I make my living working on trucks and diesel engines, so I get that the economy runs on machines that burn fuel, and you can’t just slam the brakes on that without wrecking people’s jobs. At the same time, we all have to live on this planet, and I don’t want the air and water turning to sludge for my future kids just so some big company can squeeze a little more profit. Climate policy should be like tuning an engine: tighten the standards steadily, push cleaner tech, and cut waste, but do it in a way that lets regular workers and small shops adapt instead of getting totaled by sudden government mandates.

I believe we need a practical balance where we protect the environment without crippling the economy or driving up costs for working families. Climate policy should focus on innovation, efficiency, and gradual, realistic changes—like incentivizing cleaner technologies and responsible energy use—rather than heavy-handed regulations that hurt small businesses and jobs. We’re called to be good stewards of God’s creation, but also to protect people’s livelihoods and keep the country strong and secure.

I think protecting the environment has to come first, because if we ruin the planet, there won’t be any strong economy left for my generation or the ones after us. But I also believe we should help businesses and workers transition by investing in clean energy, green jobs, and new technologies so people don’t get left behind. Climate policies should be fair, meaning big polluters and wealthy companies take more responsibility, while ordinary families and communities get support to adapt and succeed.

My dad says we have to take care of the planet because it’s our only home, and I think that’s more important than making lots of money. I like trees and animals and want the air to stay clean so I can play outside and draw pictures of nature. Grown-ups should make rules so people can still have jobs, but they shouldn’t let factories or cars hurt the Earth too much.

As a teacher and someone who cares deeply about my community’s future, I don’t see environmental protection and economic growth as opposites—we can and must design climate policies that do both. We should invest aggressively in clean energy, green infrastructure, and climate-resilient schools and neighborhoods, creating good-paying jobs while cutting emissions and pollution. Short-term profits for a few shouldn’t outweigh the long-term health and stability of our students, our towns, and our planet.

I think we have to stop treating environmental protection and economic growth like they’re enemies. We should be investing in clean energy, public transit, and greener tech so we can create good-paying jobs while cutting emissions, instead of clinging to old, polluting industries that won’t last. For people like me working retail and just trying to live a stable life, policies need to protect the planet without putting all the costs on working families—big corporations that profited from pollution should carry most of the financial burden. Environmental policy should be about fairness and long-term sustainability, not short-term profit.

Growing up and working around livestock, I’ve seen firsthand how much farmers rely on stable weather and healthy land, so I believe protecting the environment is essential to protecting our livelihoods. At the same time, climate policy shouldn’t crush small businesses or rural communities with regulations they can’t afford. The right balance is encouraging practical, science-based solutions—like improving efficiency, supporting conservation practices, and investing in cleaner technology—while keeping the economy strong and people working. As a conservative and a Jew, I see this as a responsibility to be good stewards of God’s creation without abandoning common sense or hurting families who depend on agriculture.

I believe we need to be good stewards of God’s creation, but we also have to protect working families and keep our economy strong. Climate policies should focus on practical, market-based solutions—like encouraging cleaner technology and energy efficiency—without killing jobs, driving up energy costs, or putting an unfair burden on small businesses and middle-class households.

We need to stop talking like protecting the environment and growing the economy are enemies; a smart, limited-government climate policy can do both by getting the rules simple, predictable, and technology-neutral. I don’t want DC micromanaging every lightbulb, but I do want strong incentives for cleaner energy, more resilience for communities, and fewer subsidies that prop up polluters or big corporations. Let markets and innovation lead the way, set clear guardrails to protect air, water, and public health, and then get out of the way so people and businesses can adapt and thrive.

Working at a residential care facility, I see how important stable jobs are, but I also spend my free time in nature and can’t ignore how fragile the environment is. I think climate policy should put environmental protection first, with strong rules on pollution and clean energy, while making sure workers and low-income communities get support, retraining, and new opportunities in green industries. Economic growth that destroys the planet or harms people’s health isn’t real progress, but we can grow in ways that are cleaner, fairer, and better for everyone.

As someone who spent a career in the military and knows how important a strong economy is for national security, I believe climate policy has to protect both our environment and our livelihoods. We should invest in practical, market-driven solutions—like cleaner energy technology and conservation incentives—without overregulating businesses or killing good-paying jobs. I love the outdoors and want to preserve our natural resources, but changes need to be gradual, realistic, and focused on innovation rather than heavy-handed government mandates.

As someone who has spent a lifetime studying how great civilizations flourished and then collapsed, I am convinced that sacrificing the environment for short-term economic gain is historically shortsighted and ultimately self-destructive. Climate policy should put environmental protection at the center, with economic growth redefined around sustainable industries, green technology, and long‑term resilience rather than fossil-fuel–driven expansion. A prosperous society built on a degraded planet is an illusion; responsible growth must operate within ecological limits, or it simply will not last.
